newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Iraq wants oil phase to start on aid date - MEES.
newsitem.headline: Iraq wants oil phase to start on aid date - MEES.

text.p: Iraq wants the next 90-day oil export period under the United Nations' "oil-for-food" deal to start from the date U.N. secretary-general Kofi Annan approves the deal's aid distribution plan, the Middle East East Economic Survey (MEES) reported on Monday.

Under the existing ground rules, the 90-day sale period began on June 8, allowing Baghdad a narrow window to attempt to export $1 billion of its oil before the expiry of the current second phase of the deal on September 6.

"Whether or not the (U.N.) Sanctions Committee will agree with the Iraqi argument remaims to be seen...If the answer is not favourable the nature of Iraq's response will be a crucial factor," MEES reported.
America's deputy to the U.N. Edward Gnehm this month confirmed the U.S. view that the current 90-day period started on June 8.

If the U.N. agreed to Baghdad's request, Iraq would export around 700-750,000 barrels per day (bpd) during the next three months rather than the theoretical two million bpd-plus rate under the curreny plan.

Iraq resumed limited oil exports in December for the first time since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Approval of the second 180-day phase starting in June became bogged down in negotiations over aid distribution.
Kofi Annan is studing the humanitarian plan.
